stream_context.summary: Kaze implements and iterates on a new “Egg Coin” (Yoshi coin) collection mission with a Sonic Adventure–style proximity radar, changes act select from 6 to 7 missions per course, and discusses broader progression plans where collected coins become a global currency used to buy upgrades that permanently change the overworld. He also debugs a missing dynamic-light object caused by a surprising Mario 64 engine parameter edge case and outlines demo release constraints (levels missing from demo will crash if forced-loaded).
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a major structure change (7th mission/act dedicated to Egg Coins) plus a core guidance system (radar) and clarifies the game’s economy/progression philosophy (coins as global currency that can change the overworld). Also contains a concrete engine discovery about object spawning that unblocks missing dynamic lights.

findings.summary: Kaze changed act select from 6 to 7 missions per course: the 7th act is always a dedicated “Find the Egg Coins” mission that grants a coin radar UI to support that objective.

The Egg Coin radar is explicitly modeled after Sonic Adventure 1’s treasure radar: icons blink faster and shift toward red as the player gets closer to the associated coin source (including moving sources like a bunny).
Kaze reconsidered making the radar a purchasable item; he leans toward making it automatically available in the Egg Coin mission to avoid players having “no hint at all” and hating the experience.
findings.quote: Imagine you have not bought the radar and you're doing mission 7 and the game doesn't give you any hint at all. That's going to suck. That's going to be a miserable experience; people are going to hate that.

findings.summary: Demo strategy: if players use a patch to access levels not included in the demo, the game will crash because those levels won’t be packaged. Kaze mentions a second demo plan that would contain only Course 1.

Coins are positioned as a meaningful global progression currency (not “worthless” collectibles). Kaze describes using coin donations to fund NPC projects (e.g., paying 500 coins to build a bridge), permanently changing the overworld as a result.
findings.quote: Trust me, the coins are not going to feel worthless. The coins are going to feel very cool… more valuable than Mario Odyssey.

findings.summary: He debugged why certain dynamic “crystal light” objects didn’t spawn/run in an area: in the Mario 64 engine, setting a behavior parameter to 255 prevents the object from spawning at all.
findings.quote: There's a functionality in the Mario 64 engine where if you set the behavior parameter to 255 the object does not spawn. This is so fucking wild.

findings.summary: Radar readability issues surfaced: blinking may be distracting, and coin colors differ by level, so using color shifts (green→red / yellow→red) in the radar can overlap with a level’s coin color and with the “collected” state, creating confusion.

UI iteration ideas discussed: slowing blink rate; switching from pure color cues to brightness/saturation; adding a pulsating halo; experimenting with transparency so icons become more solid as you get closer (and/or to distinguish uncollected/collected states).
Kaze confirmed a progression rules change: traditional 100-coin missions are removed; “points/coins are global now,” reinforcing the economy concept rather than per-level coin-star goals.

Roadmap clarity: Kaze says all main courses are planned and have some work done. He identifies Course 13 as an ice castle (outside area not finished), Course 14 as a craft world, and Course 15 as a “space arcade.”
Rumble Pack support is currently disabled; Kaze frames it as non-trivial because it would require a dedicated thread, and he doesn’t own a Rumble Pak to test with.

zeina.summary: Zeina is present on stream; there’s light personal banter but no clear development decision attributed directly to her in this transcript.

key_stories.title: Creating a dedicated Egg Coin mission with a Sonic Adventure–style radar
key_stories.summary: Kaze formalizes Egg Coins as a first-class objective by adding a seventh act to every course, then builds a proximity radar to make hunting feasible and fun. The segment reveals his balancing act between ‘treasure hunt’ ambiguity and avoiding player frustration.
key_stories.challenge: Egg Coin hunts risk becoming miserable if players don’t know where to search, especially if the radar were optional or hidden behind a purchase.
key_stories.process: He changes act select from 6 to 7 missions, labels the new mission “Find the Egg Coins,” and enables a radar that blinks faster/changes color as you approach each coin source. He then iterates on presentation (blink rate, halo, transparency) to reduce distraction and confusion with per-level coin colors and collected-state indicators.
key_stories.outcome: A new mission structure and guidance system is in place; Kaze is actively refining the UI language (color vs brightness vs transparency) to keep the hunt readable without over-spoiling it.
key_stories.key_quote: That's going to be a miserable experience; people are going to hate that.

key_stories.title: Missing dynamic lights traced to an engine parameter edge case
key_stories.summary: While preparing a demo build, Kaze notices certain light objects don’t appear or run despite being placed and active. The fix comes from uncovering a non-obvious engine rule that silently prevents spawning.
key_stories.challenge: Specific “crystal light” objects fail to spawn in an area for unknown reasons, raising concern about reliability for the demo.
key_stories.process: He verifies the objects are present and active, then investigates engine/spawn logic until finding a parameter value that disables spawning.
key_stories.outcome: Root cause identified: behavior parameter 255 prevents the object from spawning, unblocking the lighting pass for the area.
key_stories.key_quote: If you set the behavior parameter to 255 the object does not spawn.

key_stories.title: Coins reframed as global currency that can reshape the overworld
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains that coins will matter beyond one-off collectibles: they become global progression currency used for upgrades and world changes. This provides a documentary-friendly rationale for why exploration and collection remain meaningful across the whole game.
key_stories.challenge: Players may assume coin collection is low-value busywork unless the game clearly rewards it in impactful ways.
key_stories.process: He describes using coins to buy upgrades and fund NPC-driven projects (example: donating 500 coins to build a bridge), causing permanent overworld changes. He also states that 100-coin missions no longer exist and ‘points’ are global now.
key_stories.outcome: A clear design direction emerges: coins are the backbone of progression and world evolution rather than isolated level objectives.
key_stories.key_quote: You're actually going to affect the world by giving people money.

key_stories.title: Demo packaging constraints and crash risk from out-of-demo warps
key_stories.summary: Kaze anticipates players attempting to access content not included in the demo via patches, and he warns this will crash because those levels won’t exist in the build. He also hints at a staged demo plan.
key_stories.challenge: Preventing (or at least explaining) crashes and confusion when players force access to levels that aren’t shipped in a demo build.
key_stories.process: He clarifies that non-demo levels will be absent, so any forced warp to them will crash. He mentions planning a second demo that would include only Course 1.
key_stories.outcome: Public expectations are set: demo builds are intentionally limited; accessing cut content isn’t supported and will break.

open_questions.context: Kaze worries that blinking and color shifts are distracting and that per-level coin colors plus collected-state colors will conflict with the radar’s green→red/yellow→red feedback. He experiments with transparency and discusses alternatives like brightness/saturation and halos.
questions: What final visual rule did you land on for the radar—color shift, brightness, transparency, halo—and what was the deciding test that convinced you it was ‘readable but not spoilery’?
How did you solve the ‘coin color differs by level’ problem without making the radar lie or become visually noisy?
Did you playtest the radar with people unfamiliar with the level layouts, and what surprising behaviors did you see (e.g., confusion, motion sickness, ignoring the UI)?

open_questions.topic: Making the radar automatic vs. purchasable and how the game teaches it
open_questions.context: Kaze leans toward making the radar always available during the Egg Coin mission to avoid players entering mission 7 with no guidance and having a bad experience, but he also notes it reduces the value of buying it (and players may not know the radar exists).
questions: Did you ultimately remove the radar as a shop item entirely, or is there still an upgrade path tied to it (range, number of pings, multi-coin tracking)?
How do you introduce the Egg Coin mission and radar in-game so players understand the new 7th act and what makes it different?

open_questions.topic: Overworld-economy plan: world changes bought with coins
open_questions.context: Kaze pitches coins funding NPC projects (bridge building, overworld changing) and says coins will feel highly valuable; 100-coin missions are removed and currency is global.
questions: What are the most important overworld changes you want players to ‘buy’—and how do those changes tie into new courses, shortcuts, or narrative beats?
How did you balance coin costs so the economy feels exciting (big goals) without turning into grind?
How will you communicate ‘global currency’ clearly to players used to Mario 64’s per-level coin logic?

open_questions.topic: Demo rollout and the ‘second demo is only Course 1’ decision
open_questions.context: Kaze states that forcing access to missing levels will crash, and mentions a second demo that would contain only Course 1—an unusual choice that implies either a vertical slice strategy or a major refactor/testing need.
questions: Why make the second demo only Course 1—was it about polish, onboarding, technical stability, or controlling first impressions?
What did you consider ‘must prove’ in the demo (core mechanics, performance, art direction, economy hooks), and what did you intentionally hold back?
